tip: Always validate and sanitize user input to prevent SQL injection attacks.
Use parameterized queries or prepared statements when interacting with databases.
Implement proper authentication and authorization mechanisms to control access to resources.
Use HTTPS to encrypt data in transit and protect against man-in-the-middle attacks.
Never store sensitive information like passwords in plain text. Use strong hashing algorithms with salts.
Implement rate limiting to prevent brute force attacks on authentication endpoints.
Keep all software dependencies and libraries up to date to patch known vulnerabilities.
Use the principle of least privilege when assigning permissions to users and processes.
Implement proper error handling to avoid exposing sensitive information in error messages.
Use Content Security Policy (CSP) headers to mitigate cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.
Implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) for added security on user accounts.
Use secure random number generators for cryptographic operations and session tokens.
Implement proper session management, including secure session storage and expiration.
Use security headers like X-Frame-Options and X-XSS-Protection to enhance application security.
Implement proper input validation on both client and server sides.
